Tel.: +86 21 64252230; fax: +86 21 64253528. Graphical abstract Selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene is an important reaction for increasing the purity of the styrene monomer. In this study a series of supported nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and applied to the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. The preparation procedure consisted of two steps: synthesis of colloidal Pd nanoparticles by a reduction-by-solvent method, followed by impregnation onto α-Al2O3. In the first step, NaBH4 was used as a reducing agent to reduce Pd2+ ions in the C2H5OH/H2O solvent system, and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was used as a protecting agent to stabilize Pd nanoparticles. The prepared colloids and catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, CO chemisorption, XRD, UV–vis, FT-IR, ICP and HRTEM techniques. It was found that the amounts of NaBH4, C2H5OH and PVP had effects on the Pd particle size, which in turn influenced the catalyst performance. The selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene was sensitive to the structure of the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts. In the case where the Pd particle size varied from 3.8 to 6.6nm, the specific activity and the selectivity to styrene increased with increasing particle size, but when the particle size increased in the range of 6.6–12.1nm, the specific activity increased slowly and the selectivity to styrene decreased gradually. Nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 can be reused several times without loss of activity and selectivity and no distinct variation in the Pd particle size was observed, indicating its good stability in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. Keywords Pd nanoparticles Reduction-by-solvent Selective hydrogenation Phenylacetylene Catalyst 1 Introduction Styrene as an important monomer has been widely used for producing polystyrene and synthetic rubbers such as ABS and SB latex [1]. With the increasing demand for the styrene-related products, the annual output of styrene in the world is continuously growing, reaching about 28 million tons at 2012. Nowadays, styrene is mainly produced by two technologies, viz. dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene and epoxidation of propylene with ethylbenzene hydroperoxide [2]. However, phenylacetylene is produced when excessive dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene occurs [3]. A small amount of phenylacetylene in styrene is very difficult to separate from styrene due to their similar properties and the presence of trace phenylacetylene in styrene will poison the catalyst used in the polymerization process [4]. At present, the most effective way to remove phenylacetylene from styrene is the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. Supported precious and non-precious metal catalysts have been used in the selective hydrogenation of alkynes by many researchers. Although non-precious metal catalysts have attracted increasing interests in recent years due to low cost and good selectivity [5–8], supported precious metal catalysts are still the most widely used catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of alkynes in industry. The precious metals employed include Ni [9,10], Rh [11,12], Ru [13,14], Pt [4,15], Pd [16–18], Au [19,20], etc., and of particular interest is Pd metal owing to its excellent performance in the selective hydrogenation of alkynes [21]. More recently, Pd nanoparticles (NPs) with high catalytic activity and controlled particle size have received much attention [22]. Pd NPs can be obtained by reduction of Pd2+ ions in solution, and in this technique, the reduction method becomes very important in controlling the Pd particle size. Shao et al. [23] prepared Pd/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts by a method that made use of the CO reduction deposition of PdCl2 on SiO2-Al2O3 support at room temperature in a mixture of ethanol and water. More Pd NPs were expected to be formed on the support by prolonging treatment with CO. Redón et al. [24] synthesized Pd NPs in different solvents with different reduction methods, including the solvent itself, photoreduction, chemical reduction with sodium borohydride or sodium citrate, and ultrasonic reduction, and found that the chemical reduction method gave rise to the smallest Pd NPs. However, to date only few studies have been reported on the size control of Pd NPs in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene and on how the particle size affects the activity and selectivity of catalyst [25,26]. The support is another factor influencing the catalyst performance. The supports that have been investigated in the selective hydrogenation of alkynes include TiO2 [26–28], SiO2 [29–31], mesoporous molecular sieves such as MCM-41 and SBA-15 [25,32–35], and carbon materials [36]. Weerachawanasak et al. [27] prepared two types of Pd catalysts supported on micro- and nano-sized TiO2 by the incipient wetness impregnation method, and revealed that reduction of the catalysts by H2 at 500°C led to strong metal-support interaction for the nano-sized TiO2 supported catalyst and in turn to high catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene, but not for the micro-sized TiO2 supported one. Panpranot et al. [30] prepared sol–gel-derived nano-SiO2 supported Pd catalysts by ion-exchange method, and found that the Pd/SiO2 catalyst with palladium silicide formation showed superior catalytic performance to the commercial SiO2 supported catalyst. The improved performance of the novel catalyst was mainly ascribed to the formation of palladium silicide on the catalyst that made Pd electron deficient, which in turn led to an inhibition of styrene on the Pd surface [30]. Domínguez-Domínguez et al. [25] developed a novel method, by which MCM-41 and Al-MCM-41 were synthesized in the presence of Pd NPs, to prepare Pd/MCM-41 and Pd/Al-MCM-41 catalysts, and the performance of the resulting catalysts was much greater than that of Pd NPs in the homogeneous phase. Despite the fact that the aforementioned catalysts exhibited good performance in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene, the most widely used catalyst in industry is Pd/Al2O3 [37]. Unfortunately, few investigations have been performed on Pd/Al2O3 catalysts [25,38]. In this respect, it is necessary to study the structure–performance relationship of Pd/Al2O3 in order to rationally design and prepare high performance catalysts. In this study, we proposed a two-step technique to prepare nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts. First, colloidal Pd NPs were synthesized by reduction of palladium precursors with the aid of sodium borohydride (NaBH4) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in C2H5OH/H2O solvent system, and second, the resulting Pd NPs were deposited on the α-Al2O3 support by impregnation method. The as-prepared catalysts were detailedly characterized and tested for the catalytic performance in the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. The main aim of this work is: (1) to investigate the effects of C2H5OH, NaBH4 and PVP on the Pd particle size; and (2) to elucidate the structure–performance relationship of Pd/Al2O3 in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Pd nanoparticles The Pd NPs were synthesized by a reduction-by-solvent method, with the C2H5OH/H2O mixed solution as the solvent, NaBH4 as the reducing agent to reduce Pd2+ ions, and PVP (M W =58000) as the protecting agent to stabilize Pd NPs. In a typical synthesis, a certain amount of PVP (the molar ratio of PVP in monomer unit to Pd ranged from 20 to 100) was added into a mixture of V 1 mL of C2H5OH and V 2 mL of H2O (V 1 + V 2 =70mL, V 1/(V 1 + V 2)=0–1) at room temperature under vigorous stirring. After complete dissolution of PVP, 24mL of H2PdCl4 solution (2mmol/L) was added and stirred for 3min. Finally, a certain volume of NaBH4 solution (25mmol/L, the molar ratio of NaBH4 to Pd ranged from 0 to 3) was added into the above solution and stirred for 3h. 2.1.2 Preparation of α-Al2O3 Because of its lower specific surface area and lower acidity than other transition Al2O3 such as γ-Al2O3 or θ-Al2O3 [38], α-Al2O3 can prevent acid-catalyzed polymerization of alkenes [39], which makes α-Al2O3 more suitable for the selective hydrogenation of alkynes. Our preliminary experiments (not shown here), which compared Pd/γ-Al2O3 with Pd/α-Al2O3 (both prepared by incipient wetness impregnation) in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene, also demonstrated that Pd/α-Al2O3 had better catalytic performance than Pd/γ-Al2O3. Therefore, α-Al2O3 was used as the catalyst support in this work. The α-Al2O3 support was simply obtained by calcination of γ-Al2O3 (Alfa-Aesar 43266, c.a. 40μm) at 1200°C (with a heating ramp of 5°C/min) for 3h in a muffle furnace. 2.1.3 Preparation of nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 The catalyst was prepared by impregnation of α-Al2O3 with the aqueous solution of Pd NPs. First, a predetermined amount of α-Al2O3 was added into an aqueous solution of Pd NPs as synthesized above (0.5wt.% of theoretical Pd loading for all the catalysts in this study) at room temperature under vigorous stirring for 2 days, and then, the solid was filtered and continuously washed with absolute ethanol and deionized water for several times. Finally, the solid particles were dried at 110°C for 12h, followed by calcination at 450°C (with a heating ramp of 2°C/min) in air for 3h in order to enhance the interaction between Pd metal and α-Al2O3. For simplicity, the as-prepared catalyst is denoted by P x E y N z , where x, y and z represent the molar ratio of PVP in monomer unit to Pd, the volume fraction of C2H5OH in the mixture of C2H5OH and H2O, and the molar ratio of NaBH4 to Pd, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of samples were obtained from N2 physisorption data collected at −196°C on a Micrometrics ASAP 2010 instrument. The crystalline structure of samples was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) of a Rigaku D/Max 2550 VB/PC diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å, 40kV, and 100mA), and the data were collected from 10° to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02°. The reduction of Pd2+ ions to Pd NPs was evidenced by ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. Fourier-transformed infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples, measured over the range of 4000–400cm−1 at a resolution of 4cm−1 by a Bruker Equinox-55 spectrometer, were used to determine the presence or absence of PVP in the catalyst. The actual Pd loading of the prepared catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Varian 710ES). Before analysis the samples were treated with aqua regia to dissolve all Pd. The metal dispersion of catalysts was determined by the CO-pulse chemisorption technique using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 apparatus. The chemisorption stoichiometry of CO/Pd was assumed to be 1. The weighed catalysts were reduced in a mixture of 10% H2/Ar (100mL/min) at 400°C for 2h, followed by a switch to He (100mL/min) at 400°C for 20min to remove adsorbed H2. When the catalysts were cooled to 35°C in He, CO pulses were injected into the quartz reactor, and the signal was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). According to the CO-pulse chemisorption technique, the mean Pd particle size (d CO) was calculated from the measured dispersion value (D CO) by the following equation [40,41]: (1) d CO = 112 D CO ( % ) , nm The micro-morphology of catalyst was analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) using a JEOL JEM-2100 electron microscope operating at 200kV. The samples were prepared by dispersing the ground catalysts in ethanol under ultrasound for 30min. A drop of the suspension was then transferred onto a carbon-coated cooper grid, followed by drying at room temperature. The mean Pd particle size (d TEM) based on the HRTEM analysis was calculated by [25]: (2) d TEM = ∑ n i d i ∑ n i where n i (n i >100) is the number of particles with a diameter of d i. Assuming a spherical geometry for the Pd particle, the corresponding metal dispersion (D TEM) was given by [42]: (3) D TEM ≈ 0.9 d TEM ( nm ) × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst test Before chemical reactions the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts were reduced in a fixed-bed reactor by flowing a mixture of 50% H2/N2 at 400°C (with a heating ramp of 5°C/min) for 2h. After the catalysts were cooled to room temperature, they were withdrawn from the fixed-bed reactor for the catalytic reactions. The selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene over nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 was conducted in a 300mL glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer (Parr 5101). First, 87.6mL of ethanol (solvent), 6.85mL of phenylacetylene (reactant), 5.7mL of n-octane (internal standard) and 0.3g of the reduced catalyst were added into the reactor; second, the reactor was heated to 50°C (by circulating hot water through the jacket) with mild stirring under N2 protection, and then it was purged several times with H2 in the absence of stirring; and third, the reaction was started up at 50°C and 0.1MPa under vigorous stirring (the stirring rate used in this study was 1000rpm, under which the external mass transfer limitations were eliminated). The reactor was operated in a semi-batch mode with H2 continuously entering the reactor, and the reaction product was withdrawn at regular intervals and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (HP-6890) equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30m×0.32mm×0.5μm) and a flame ionization detector. The temperatures at the injector and the detector were 150 and 200°C, respectively. The oven temperature program was as follows: start at 60°C (hold for 4min), ramp at 5°C/min to 150°C, and finally hold at 150°C for 2min. The turnover frequency (TOF) and the selectivity to styrene were used to evaluate and compare the catalytic performance of different catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the support and the catalyst. The catalyst support (Fig. 1b) obtained by calcination of γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1a, JCPDS 10-0425) at 1200°C exhibits diffraction peaks belonging to the α-Al2O3 phase (JCPDS 10-0173). Taking the P80E0.8N2 catalyst as an example, its diffraction peaks (Fig. 1c) are almost identical to those of the support, and no peaks assigned to Pd species are detected, which is mostly caused by the low Pd loading that is below the detection limit of the XRD technique. The presence of Pd in the catalyst is clearly evidenced by HRTEM and EDS analysis. As shown in Fig. 2b, there exists palladium species in P80E0.8N2 according to the EDS analysis. In addition, the distance of 2.25Å between the adjacent lattice fringes (Fig. 2d) agrees well with the (111) lattice spacing of cubic metallic palladium NPs [43]. Note that Cu and C presented in the EDS spectrum are attributed to copper grids and carbon film, respectively. The textural properties of the support and the P80E0.8N2 catalyst are listed in Table 1 . As expected, the BET surface area and pore volume of α-Al2O3 are much smaller than those of γ-Al2O3, owing to collapse of the pore structure and loss of internal surface area produced by the irreversible phase transition. The BET surface area and pore volume of α-Al2O3 are almost equal to those of P80E0.8N2, but the average pore diameter of the former is little larger than that of the latter, indicating partial blockage of pores in the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the FT-IR spectra of PVP and the P100E0.8N2 catalyst after washing with ethanol and water. The characteristic peaks belonging to PVP (Fig. 3a) include: the CN stretching vibration peak centered at 1290cm−1, the ring CC stretching vibration at 1460cm−1, the CO vibration at 1650cm−1, the ring CH vibration in the region of 2800–3000cm−1 and the OH stretching vibration in the region of 3180−3450cm−1 [44]. It should be noted that very small peaks assigned to PVP are present for P100E0.8N2 (Fig. 3b), implying that a trace amount of PVP still exist even after washing treatment, owing to the interaction between PVP and Pd [45]. However, the effect of trace PVP on the activity and selectivity of the catalyst can be neglected, considering the competitive adsorption between PVP and phenylacetylene and the relatively much smaller amount of PVP in comparison with phenylacetylene [46]. In addition, a weak OH stretching vibration was detected for P100E0.8N2 due to a small amount of H2O adsorbed in the P100E0.8N2 catalyst. Fig. 4 shows the HRTEM images of Pd(P20E0.8N2) and Pd(P80E0.8N2) colloids as well as the corresponding supported catalysts P20E0.8N2 and P80E0.8N2. The inserted histograms display the Pd particle size distribution of each sample. A comparison between Fig. 4a and b or between Fig. 4c and d clearly indicates that the particle size (d TEM) of the Pd colloid is smaller than that of the supported catalyst, which is mainly due to growth of Pd particles during the calcination process [25]. However, a comparison between reduced and unreduced catalysts (not shown here) shows nearly no variation in the Pd particle size, indicating the negligible effect of the H2 reduction treatment at 400°C on the Pd particle size. Fig. 5 shows the HRTEM images of various catalysts and the corresponding histograms of the Pd particle size distribution. The mean Pd particle sizes and the metal dispersions determined from CO chemisorption and HRTEM analyses are summarized in Table 2 . The effect of NaBH4 on the Pd particle size of catalyst can be seen by comparing P80E0.4N0, P80E0.4N1, P80E0.4N2 and P80E0.4N3 catalysts (see Figs. 5a–d and Table 2). With an increase in the molar ratio of NaBH4 to Pd ([NaBH4]/[Pd]), the Pd particle size first decreases and then remains constant. This trend results mainly from different reduction capabilities of NaBH4 and C2H5OH. It is well known that NaBH4 is a strong reducing agent, but C2H5OH also has the capability of reducing metal ions, as proposed by Redón et al. [24]: (4) CH3CH2OH→CH3CHO+2H+ +2e− (5) Pd2+ +2e− →Pd0 In addition, Teranishi and Miyake [47] used three kinds of alcohol as reducing agents to prepare Pd NPs with the mean particle size of 2–5nm under reflux, and found that the reduction rate followed the order of methanol>ethanol>1-propanol. Wang and Tseng [48] prepared monodispersed Pt NPs by reducing H2PtCl6 with ethanol at 95°C. Note that heating is normally required for reducing metal ions to NPs when only alcohols are used as the reducing agents. However, in the present study, the reduction process is carried out at room temperature, which inevitably results in a slow reduction rate of Pd2+ ions if only ethanol is used, and it is very difficult to control the Pd particle size when the reduction rate is slow. This is the reason that P80E0.4N0 has a broad Pd particle size distribution and some particles even have a diameter of around 29nm (Fig. 5a). In contrast, NaBH4 is a strong reducing agent and the presence of NaBH4 vastly facilitates the reduction of Pd2+, and consequently small and uniform particle size distribution is obtained under the coupling effects of C2H5OH and NaBH4 (Figs. 5b–d). The effect of the [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio on reduction of Pd2+ ions can be further disclosed by using UV–vis spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 6 , the H2PdCl4 in a mixture of ethanol and water (sample a) exhibits a maximum at 420nm, which is assigned to the Pd2+ ions [23,49]. As the [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio increases (samples b–d), the absorbance at 420nm decreases or even disappears for the Pd(P80E0.4N2) colloid obtained after 3h of reduction. Meanwhile, a broad shoulder at around 380–400nm appears, and the absorbance in this region increases with the increased [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio, indicating the formation of Pd NPs [49]. It should be noted that ethanol makes a weak reduction of Pd2+ at room temperature (sample b) and the presence of NaBH4 leads to a rapid reduction of Pd2+ (sample b vs. sample c), but a further increase in the [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio only causes a slight increase in the absorbance (sample c vs. sample d). In fact, the Pd(P80E0.4N3) colloid (not shown here) displays an identical UV–vis spectrum to Pd(P80E0.4N2), implying that all the Pd2+ ions in the solution have been reduced to metallic Pd when the [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio is 2. The results obtained by UV–vis spectral analysis agrees well with those derived from the HRTEM analysis. The molar ratio of PVP to Pd ([PVP]/[Pd]) is another factor influencing the Pd particle size of catalyst, and this effect can be seen by comparison of P20E0.8N2, P60E0.8N2, P80E0.8N2 and P100E0.8N2 (see Figs. 5e–h as well as Table 2). With the increase of the [PVP]/[Pd] ratio from 20 to 80, the mean Pd particle size (d CO) decreases from 7.6nm to 3.8nm, but further increasing this ratio to 100 results in an increase in the Pd particle size (5.4nm). This result is mainly ascribed to the protective effect of PVP on Pd particles. Being a protective polymer for metallic NPs, PVP can adsorb on the surface of Pd particles in the solvent via the coordination of the CO group with the Pd atoms, which in turn prevents the synthesized Pd particles from aggregation [47,50]. The concentration of PVP at low [PVP]/[Pd] ratio (such as 20) is insufficient to cover the Pd particle surface and, as a result, leads to particle aggregation and large Pd NPs [48]. With the increase of the [PVP]/[Pd] ratio, the coverage of PVP on the Pd particle surface increases, giving rise to the improved protective effect and hence small Pd NPs. When the [PVP]/[Pd] ratio is 80, the optimal coverage of PVP on the Pd particle surface is probably attained, and the smallest Pd NPs are therefore obtained in the given solvent. However, when the [PVP]/[Pd] ratio is further increased up to 100, the coalescence of Pd NPs occurs due to the formation of bridges between PVP macromolecule chains [51], which accounts for the increased Pd particle size. The influence of the C2H5OH concentration on Pd particle size of catalyst is studied by comparing P80E0N2, P80E0.4N2, P80E0.8N2 and P80E1N2 (see Fig. 5i, c, g and j as well as Table 2). It is found that the Pd particle size first decreases and then increases with the increase of the C2H5OH concentration. As discussed above, C2H5OH is a weak reducing agent, which can reduce Pd2+ at a slow reduction rate. Thus, for a given [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio, the increase of the C2H5OH concentration in the solvent mixture is presumed to favor the formation of smaller Pd NPs. However, at higher C2H5OH concentration, the inhomogeneous dispersion of H2PdCl4 in solution takes place because H2PdCl4 is much less soluble in C2H5OH, which leads to the formation of larger Pd NPs [47]. Therefore, a minimum in the Pd particle size is observed with the increased C2H5OH concentration. 3.2 Catalytic performance The initial reaction rates and the corresponding TOF values for various catalysts are listed in Table 3 . These data are calculated from experimental results obtained at 8min of reaction time when the conversion of phenylacetylene is lower than 20%. For each catalyst, the experiments were repeated twice with similar results (relative error of the repeated experiments ≤5%), indicating the good reproducibility. The catalytic performances of these catalysts are further compared by plotting the selectivity to styrene against the conversion of phenylacetylene, as shown in Figs. 7–9 . For P80E0.4N0, P80E0.4N1, P80E0.4N2 and P80E0.4N3 catalysts used to study the effect of the [NaBH4]/[Pd] ratio, it can be observed that the TOF value (Table 3) and the selectivity to styrene at almost complete conversion of phenylacetylene (Fig. 7) depend on the Pd particle size (Table 2). It seems that higher specific activity and selectivity could be obtained with larger particle size, and lower specific activity and selectivity with smaller particle size. Similar results are also obtained for P20E0.8N2, P60E0.8N2, P80E0.8N2 and P100E0.8N2 with regard to the effect of the [PVP]/[Pd] ratio (Fig. 8), and for P80E0N2, P80E0.4N2, P80E0.8N2 and P80E1N2 with regard to the effect of the C2H5OH concentration (Fig. 9). Nevertheless, if all TOF (or selectivity to styrene) data are plotted against the Pd particle size, an interesting phenomenon is observed. As shown in Fig. 10 , the TOF value increases with increasing Pd particle size over the whole range investigated (3.8–12.1nm), but the increase becomes gentle when the particle size is above 6.6nm. However, there exists a maximum value in the selectivity curve, which is about 60% (at total conversion) at 6.6nm of Pd particle size. When the Pd particle size is larger than 6.6nm, the selectivity to styrene gradually decreases, demonstrating that the selectivity of over-hydrogenation (formation of ethylbenzene) is increased. The variations of the specific activity and the selectivity to styrene with the Pd particle size clearly indicate that the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene is sensitive to the structure of the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalyst. The structure-sensitive characteristic of this reaction was also reported by other researchers. Domínguez-Domínguez et al. [25] found that the TOF values increased with increasing Pd particle size between 3 and 13nm. Panpranot et al. [30] pointed out that the TOF values decreased by an order of magnitude when the Pd particle size was smaller than 3–5nm. In an early study on the hydrogenation of 1-butyne over Pd/Al2O3, Boitiaux et al. [52] found that the TOF values increased with an increase in the Pd particle size from 0.4 to 4.2nm, but remained constant when the particle size varied from 4.2 to 11.2nm. Recently, Ruta et al. [53] reported that the TOF values of acetylene selective hydrogenation over Pd/CNFs increased with the Pd particle size from 8 to 11nm, but were unchanged from 11 to 13nm. These investigations showed that increasing Pd particle size led to an increase in the specific activity especially over catalysts with small Pd particle size. The variation of the specific activity with the Pd particle size is believed to be caused by electronic and geometric effects [54]. The strong complexation of the highly unsaturated phenylacetylene to Pd atoms with low coordination numbers on small Pd NPs is unfavorable for achieving high specific activity in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. With regard to the selectivity, Weerachawanasak et al. [26] found that the selectivity to styrene over Pd/TiO2 catalysts decreased with decreasing the Pd particle size in the range of 3.2–5.9nm, agreeing with the present study (3.8–6.6nm), which was ascribed to the longer residence time of styrene on smaller Pd particles. With a further increase in the Pd particle size from 6.6 to 12.1nm, the selectivity to styrene, however, decreases slowly, which is probably caused by the formation of β-PdH phase [54]. The β-PdH phase is believed to contribute to the over-hydrogenation of alkynes, and the probability of formation of this phase is known to increase with increasing the Pd particle size [54–56]. In the end, the reusability of nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene is evaluated. Five consecutive cycles were performed using the P80E0.8N2 catalyst under the same reaction conditions as mentioned in Section 2.3. For each cycle, the product after 28min of reaction was used for analysis and comparison. As shown in Fig. 11 , both activity and selectivity remain very well in 5 cycles. Fig. 12 shows the Pd particle size of the used catalyst, and it is clear that no distinct variation in the Pd particle size occurs in comparison with the original catalyst (Fig. 5g). In addition, the Pd loading of the used catalyst after 5 cycles is still 0.47wt.% (determined by ICP), the same as the original value, indicating no Pd leaching from the catalyst during the cyclic operation. All these results demonstrate the good stability of the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalyst in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. 4 Conclusion In this work, colloidal Pd NPs were first synthesized by reduction of palladium precursors with the aid of NaBH4 and PVP in C2H5OH/H2O solvent system, and then deposited on α-Al2O3 by impregnation to give the corresponding supported nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts, which were finally applied to the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. A series of catalysts were prepared by adjusting the amounts of NaBH4, PVP and C2H5OH used. It was found that with an increase in the molar ratio of NaBH4 to Pd, the Pd particle size first decreased and then remained constant, and with an increase in the molar ratio of PVP in monomer unit to Pd or an increase in the C2H5OH concentration, the Pd particle size first decreased and then increased. The effects of the amounts of NaBH4, PVP and C2H5OH on the Pd particle size resulted in different catalytic performances of the catalysts. The specific activity and the selectivity to styrene depended on the Pd particle size, implying the structure-sensitive characteristic of the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene over the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts. Reusability tests showed that the catalysts can be used repeatedly without notable deactivation related to Pd leaching or agglomeration under the reaction conditions used. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene is an important reaction for increasing the purity of the styrene monomer. In this study a series of supported nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and applied to the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. The preparation procedure consisted of two steps: synthesis of colloidal Pd nanoparticles by a reduction-by-solvent method, followed by impregnation onto α-Al2O3. In the first step, NaBH4 was used as a reducing agent to reduce Pd2+ ions in the C2H5OH/H2O solvent system, and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was used as a protecting agent to stabilize Pd nanoparticles. The prepared colloids and catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, CO chemisorption, XRD, UV–vis, FT-IR, ICP and HRTEM techniques. It was found that the amounts of NaBH4, C2H5OH and PVP had effects on the Pd particle size, which in turn influenced the catalyst performance. The selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene was sensitive to the structure of the nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalysts. In the case where the Pd particle size varied from 3.8 to 6.6nm, the specific activity and the selectivity to styrene increased with increasing particle size, but when the particle size increased in the range of 6.6–12.1nm, the specific activity increased slowly and the selectivity to styrene decreased gradually. Nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 can be reused several times without loss of activity and selectivity and no distinct variation in the Pd particle size was observed, indicating its good stability in the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene over a nano-Pd/α-Al2O3 catalyst
